awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: The Theory and Practice of Key Derivation
awd_abstract_narration:
Most cryptographic applications crucially rely on secret keys that are chosen randomly and are unknown to an attacker. Unfortunately, the process of deriving secret keys in practice is often difficult, error-prone and riddled with security vulnerabilities. Badly generated keys offer a prevalent source of attacks that render complex cryptographic applications completely insecure, despite their sophisticated design and rigorous mathematical analysis.  Even though key derivation plays a central role in the security landscape, it has received surprisingly little formal study within the cryptographic community, leading to a large disconnect between the theory and practice.
 
In this project, several important scenarios for key derivation are examined for their capability to improve security with provable guarantees, including the use of random number generators (RNGs), passwords, and biometrics.  In particular:
 
- How RNGs are designed to properly combine the entropy gathering, randomness extraction and pseudorandom generation modules, while achieving the best possible subset of clearly defined security properties against a variety of adversarial scenarios.
 
- How to reduce the effectiveness of ?offline dictionary attacks? when generating keys from passwords.
 
- How biometrics can be safely reused to generate many secret keys across many applications raises several interesting questions, combining cryptographic security properties with those of error-correcting codes.

por.por_cntn:
The project studied the fundamental problem of key derivation and random number generation (RNG).

In terms of intellectual merit, we found practical attacks on the Linux's RNG /dev/random, and showed the first theoretical analysis (and improvements) of Windows RNG called Fortuna. In addition to attacking/analyzing these existing RNG constructions, we also designed a new theoretical framework for building and rigorously analyzing RNGs, and designed several new and provably secure RNGs in our framework, which provide both qualitative and quantitative security and efficiency improvements to known RNG constructions.

We also studied the problem of key derivation, which is a fundamental cryptographic problem of how to convert an imperfect entropy source into the longest possible nearly uniform cryptographic key. Previous solutions to this problem achieved this task, but at the expense of extracting a key which was noticeably shorter than the entropy of the source. In fact, some prior work even suggested that such non-trivial "entropy loss" is inherent to the problem. In a very surprising result, we showed that this intuition is wrong, by designing the first provably secure key derivation functions (for a large collection of cryptographic applications) which achieve almost no entropy loss. Given that many entropy sources have very little entropy to begin with, our work will likely have a significant impact in practice.

We also developed novel and nearly optimal solutions for the privacy amplification (PA) problem, which is a two-party variant of the key derivation problem, where parties an imperfectly random secret, and wish to agree on the longest possible truly random secret, despite interacting over a public communication channel completely controlled by a computationally unbounded attacker. 

We also developed novel techniques for the problem of "non-malleable" key dervation. In this setting, the secret is encoded in a special form, that that a large class of practical tampering attacks on this encoding can either produce the same secret (so they do not succeed), or produce an unrelated secret (which has limited or no damage for many applications). In particular, we construct such "non-malleable codes"  resisting all attacks that either (1) are restricted to tampering two components of the physical device in an independent/uncoordianted manner, (2) are of sufficiently low computational complexity. This covers many realistic types of tampering attacks that are likely to be encountered in practice. 

In terms of broader impact,  we actively involve  Ph.D. students and postdocs at Northeastern and NYU in all aspects of this project. By engaging students in the kinds of cross-disciplinary research performed in this project, we helped to prepare the next generation of engineers and researchers to more closely intertwine theory and systems. Along with advising, we used the results of this work in undergraduate and graduate curriculum that intertwines systems and theory. In particular, PI Dodis already taught highly successful special-topic courses on Exposure-Resilient Cryptography, Randomness in Cryptography and Basing Cryptography on Imperfect Randomness, which are directly related to the topic of this proposal. He has also published extensive notes on various courses that he taught, and his notes for the Introduction to Cryptography course have been used extensively by researchers at various universities, including UC Irvine and CUNY. This project also made effort to  involve women and underrepresented minorities in the research, including a student and a postdoc.

Modified by: Yevgeniy Dodis
